== Topography == {{Moldavian Plateau}} [[Image:MoldRelief.jpg|thumb|left|Topography of Moldova]] Most of Moldova's territory is a moderate hilly plateau cut deeply by many streams and rivers. Geologically, Moldova lies primarily on deep sedimentary rock that gives way to harder crystalline outcroppings only in the north. Moldova's hills are part of the [[Moldavian Plateau]], which geologically originate from the [[Carpathian Mountains]].
The northern landscape of Moldova is characterized by gently rolling uplands of the [[Dniester Hills]] (up to {{convert|300|m|ft|0|abbr=on|disp=or}}, in [[elevation]]) interlaced with small flat plains in the valleys of the numerous [[Stream|creeks]] (at {{convert|150|m|ft|0|abbr=on|disp=or}} elevation). These hills, which have an average altitude of {{convert|240|m|ft|0|sp=us}} and a maximum altitude of {{convert|320|m|ft|0|sp=us}}, can be divided into the [[Northern Moldavian Hills]] and the [[Dniester Ridge]], and continue further occupying the northern part of the [[Chernivtsi oblast]] in [[Ukraine]]. The eastern slopes of the Dniester Ridge (average {{convert|250|m|ft|0|sp=us|disp=or}}, max {{convert|347|m|ft|0|sp=us|disp=or}}), form the high right bank of the Dniester River.
The [[Moldavian Plain]] has an average of {{convert|200|m|ft|0|sp=us}} and a maximum altitude of {{convert|250|m|ft|0|sp=us}}, and can be divided into the [[Bălți Steppe]] and the [[Middle Prut Valley]]. Originally [[forest]]ed, it has been extensively de-forested for [[agriculture]] during the 19th and 20th centuries. In contrast to the region to the north and south, which is smore slant, this area is referred to as ''plain'', although it has [[Terrain|relief]] very different from that of a [[flatlands|flatland]], and vegetation different from that of the [[steppe]]. [[Image:MoldGeologica.jpg|thumb|Geology of Moldova]] The hills of central Moldova, the [[Central Moldavian Plateau]], at an average elevation of about {{convert|350|to|400|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, are ridges interlaced by deep, flat valleys, ravines, and landslide-scoured depressions. Steep forest-clad slopes account for much of the terrain, where the most common trees are hornbeam, oak, linden, maple, wild pear, and wild cherry. The term ''[[Codri]]'' refers more generally to all the forests between the Carpathians and the [[Dniester]] river, and even more generally to all forests in the area of the [[Carpathians]], yet since in Moldova most of them were preserved in the central part, Codri sometimes can colloquially refer to the remaining forests in the hills west and north of [[Chişinău]]. The Dniester Ridge border Central Moldavian Plateau to the north along the river [[Răut]].
The plateau can be divided into 5 parts: [[Ciuluc-Soloneţ Hills]] ({{lang-ro|Dealurile Ciuluc-Soloneţ}}), alongated in the north along the right side of the [[Răut river]], {{convert|1690|km2|mi2|0|abbr=on}}, [[Corneşti Hills]] ({{lang-ro|Dealurile Corneştilor}}), also known as Cordi Hills ({{lang-ro|Dealurile Codrilor}}), {{convert|4740|km2|mi2|0|abbr=on}}, [[Lower Dniester Hills]] ({{lang-ro|Dealurile Nistrului Inferior}}), alongated to the south of the Botna river, {{convert|3040|km2|mi2|0|abbr=on}}, [[Tigheci Hills]] ({{lang-ro|Dealurile Tigheciului}}), alongated in the south along the left side of the [[Prut river]], {{convert|3550|km2|mi2|0|abbr=on}}, and between the latter and the Prut river, the [[Lower Prut Valley]] ({{lang-ro|Valea Prutului Inferior}}), {{convert|1810|km2|mi2|0|abbr=on}}.
The country's highest point, [[Bălăneşti Hill]], which reaches {{convert|1407|or|1410|ft|m|1|abbr=on}}, depending on the source, is situated in the Corneşti Hills, the western part of the Central Moldavian Plateau. Northwest of it are the [[Ciuluc-Soloneţ Hills]] (average {{convert|250|m|ft|0|sp=us|disp=or}}, max {{convert|388|m|ft|0|sp=us|disp=or}}). In the south, the [[Tigheci|Tigheci Hills]] (average {{convert|200|m|ft|0|sp=us|disp=or}}, max {{convert|301|m|ft|0|sp=us|disp=or}}) are a prolongation, and run to the south parallel to the Lower Prut Valley.
To the south-east, the southern part of the Central Moldavian Plateau, which averages {{convert|150|-|200|m|ft|0|sp=us}}, max {{convert|250|m|ft|0|sp=us}}, and has numerous ravines and gullies, gradually vanishs into the extensive Bugeac Plain, with most of the [[Budjak]] region already in Ukraine.
[[Transnistria]] (the left bank of the Dniester) has spurs of the [[Podolian Plateau]] ({{lang-ro|Podişul Podoliei}}, {{lang-uk|Volyno-Podil's'ka vysochyna}}), (average {{convert|180|m|ft|0|sp=us|disp=or}}, max {{convert|275|m|ft|0|sp=us|disp=or}}), which are cut into by tributaries of the Dniester River. The southern half of Transnistria, the ''Lower Dniester Plain'', can be regarded as the western end of the [[Eurasian steppe]]''',''' and has an average elevation of {{convert|100|m|ft|0|sp=us}}, with a maximum of {{convert|170|m|ft|0|sp=us}}. The high right bank and low left bank of the Dniester are in sharp contrast here, where visibility is not impeded by forests.
About 75 percent of Moldova is covered by a soil type called [[Chernozem|black earth]] or [[chernozem]]. In the northern hills, more clay textured soils are found; in the south, red-earth soil is predominant. The soil becomes less fertile toward the south but can still support grape and sunflower production. The hills have woodland soils, while a small portion in southern Moldova is in the [[steppe]] zone, although most steppe areas today are cultivated. The lower reaches of the Prut and Dniester rivers and the southern river valleys are saline marshes.
Drainage in Moldova is to the south, toward the Black Sea lowlands, and eventually into the Black Sea, but only eight rivers and creeks extend more than 100 kilometers. Moldova's main river, the [[Dniester]], is navigable throughout almost the entire country, and in warmer winters it does not freeze over. The [[Prut]] river is a tributary of the [[Danube]], which it joins at the far southwestern tip of the country. Over 95% of the water circulation in Moldova flows into one of the two rivers - the Prut or Dniester. Of Moldova's well-developed network of about 3,000 creeks and streams, all draining south to the Black Sea, only 246 exceed {{convert|6|mi|km|1|abbr=on}} in length, and only 8 exceed {{convert|60|mi|km|1|abbr=on}}.
Underground water, extensively used for the country's water supply, includes about 2,200 natural springs. The terrain favours construction of reservoirs of various size.
=== Extreme points === {{Main|Extreme points of Moldova}} * The lowest point: An unnamed point on the bank of the [[Dniester River]] {{cvt|2|m|ft|2}} * The highest point: [[Bălăneşti Hill|Dealul Bălăneşti]] {{cvt|430|m|ft|0}} * North extreme: [[Naslavcea]] * South extreme: [[Giurgiuleşti]] * West extreme: [[Criva, Briceni|Criva]] * East extreme: [[Palanca, Ştefan Vodă|Palanca]]
== Natural habitat == [[Image:MoldVeget.jpg|thumb|Natural habitat of Moldova]] [[Image:Dniester in Moldova, 2004.jpg|thumb|A [[Nistru]] valley view.]] Moldova's natural habitat is characterized by [[forest steppe]]s, a temperate-climate habitat type composed of [[grassland]] interspersed with areas of [[woodland]] or [[forest]]. A belt of forest steppes cross [[Eurasia]] from eastern Europe to Eastern Siberia, forming a transition between [[temperate broadleaf and mixed forests]] and [[temperate grasslands]]. In the 19th century Moldova witnessed a sharp decrease in the forested areas, sacrificed for agriculture due to rich soil.
{| class="wikitable" |+ ! | land formation<ref>[http://www.biotica-moldova.org/ECO-NET/part6-2-2.htm Concept of National Ecological Network of the Republic of Moldova<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ! | area, km² ! | of which currently forests, km² ! | % forests ! | habitat type |- | [[Northern Moldavian Hills]] || 4,630 || 476 || 10.3% || [[forest steppe]] |- | [[Dniester Ridge|Dniester-Rāut Ridge]] || 2,480 || 363 || 14.6% || forest steppe |- | [[Middle Prut Valley]] || 2,930 || 312 || 10.6% || forest steppe |- | [[Bălți Steppe]] || 1,920 || 51 || 2.7% || [[steppe]] |- | [[Ciuluc-Soloneţ Hills]] || 1,690 || 169 || 10.0% || forest steppe |- | [[Corneşti Hills|Corneşti Hills (Codru)]] || 4,740 || 1,300 || 27.5% || [[forest]] |- | [[Lower Dniester Hills]] || 3,040 || 371 || 12.2% || forest steppe |- | [[Lower Prut Valley]] || 1,810 || 144 || 8.0% || forest steppe |- | [[Tigheci Hills]] || 3,550 || 533 || 15.0% || forest steppe |- | [[Bugeac Plain]] || 3,210 || 195 || 6.1% || steppe |- | part of [[Podolian Plateau]] || 1,920 || 175 || 9.1% || forest steppe |- | part of [[Eurasian Steppe]] || 1,920 || 140 || 7.3% || steppe |- | '''Total''' || '''33,840''' || '''4,228''' || '''12,5%''' || '''forest steppe''' |}
== Environment == [[File:Stamp of Moldova 285.gif|thumb]] [[File:Stamp of Moldova 125.gif|thumb|[[Pădurea Domnească]]]] [[File:Stamp of Moldova 359.gif|thumb|[[Lower Prut]]]] [[File:Stamp of Moldova 293.gif|thumb]]
===Historical references===
* In the 5th century BC, [[Herodotus]] visited the countryside between the rivers Dnister and Prut and described the place as "a plain with deep black earth, rich in grass and well irrigated". * Lithuanian Prince [[Jogaila]] spoke of [[Moldavia]] as "a rich and fructiferous country". * According to the testimony of [[Venetian Mateus de Murano]], "the country was very well located, reach with cattle and all kinds of fruits, pastures are perfect". * Rich natural resources of Moldavia always attracted nomads. Fleeing their devastating incursions, inhabitants of Moldavia left the brooded places and hid in forests. French knight [[Guilbert de Lannoy]], who visited these places in 1421, has mentioned insignificant population of the region: "we moved through large deserts". * Counsellor of Hungarian King [[George Reihersdorf]] (middle of 16th century) was complaining of travel through "empty, uninhabited lands". In 1541, he produced the first geographical map (preserved to this day) of the [[Principality of Moldavia]], with rivers [[Dnister]] and [[Prut]] shown, as well as cities and other localities, but also highlighted large steppes. * A map of Moldavia was drawn by the German diplomat [[Sigismund von Herberstein]]. On his map one can see woodless spaces - [[Bălți steppe]] in the north, and [[Bugeac Steppe]] in the south. * In the 17th century, pilgrims [[Pavel Aleppskii]] (a Syrian deacon) and [[Ioan Lukianov]] (a Russian preast) traveled on their way to the [[Holy land]] through Moldavia. These two travellers were struck by the disastrous state of the land that used to blossom: "It better be not ravaged, as no other such can be found, it may yield any kind". * English traveller [[John Bell (traveller)|John Bell]], who also visited Moldavia, and wrote about fecund soils and "small nice towns" situated next to [[Răut]]. * Russian geographer [[K. Laksman]] described Bălți steppe in the beginning of the 19th century: "To the north is located a steppe with almost no trees at all. To the north-west the steppe is not as woodless". * Scientist [[K. Arseniev]] mentioned that the north of [[Bessarabia]] is "a genuine mix of arid steppes with most fertile pastures, rich meadows and gardens". * Travelers and scholars were amazed by the contrast between rich natural resources of Moldavia/Bălți steppe and its low population in war torned 18th century, pitiful state of agriculture, as well as the poverty of the local population. * "Desert, waste, naked steppe... The settling among limitless expanses of Bălți steppe happened not "in accordnace" with logic, but "against" it. The life of remote ancestors of Bălțiers was full of difficulties and crosses, but they managed to resist."{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} * "Moldavian fields, as described by both ancient and contemporary writers, are great in their fertility, by far surpassing the richness of the mountains" ([[Dimitrie Cantemir]], ''[[:s:la:Descriptio Moldaviae|Descriptio Moldaviae]]'') * "Will someone describe Bessarabian steppes, indeed, they do merit a description. However for this, one needs the talent of unforgettable [[Gogol]], who has so beautifully depicted us the steppes of his homeland. And Bessarabian steppes are not less beautiful." ([[Constantin Stamati-Ciurea]])
=== Current issues === Moldova's communist-era environmental legacy, like that of many other former Soviet republics, is one of environmental degradation. [[Agriculture|Agricultural]] practices such as overuse of [[pesticide]]s and artificial fertilizers were intended to increase agricultural output at all costs, without regard for the consequences. As a result, Moldova's soil and groundwater were contaminated by lingering chemicals, some of which (including [[DDT]]) have been banned in the West.
Such practices continue in Moldova to the present day. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/news_98881.htm|title=Destroying dangerous pesticides in Moldova|last=NATO|website=NATO|access-date=2016-11-11}}</ref> In the early 1990s, use of pesticides in Moldova averaged approximately twenty times that of other former Soviet republics and Western nations. In addition, poor farming methods, such as destroying forests to plant vineyards, have contributed to the extensive soil erosion to which the country's rugged topography is already prone.
== International environmental agreements == ''party to:'' [[Air Pollution]], [[Air Pollution-Persistent Organic Pollutants]], [[Biodiversity]], [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|Climate Change]], [[Kyoto Protocol|Climate Change-Kyoto Protocol]], [[Desertification]], [[Endangered Species]], [[Hazardous Wastes]], [[Ozone Layer Protection]], [[Ship Pollution]], [[Wetlands]]
''signed, but not ratified:'' none of the selected agreements

revision.text:
{{For|global climate change during Earth's history|Climate change}} {{merge to|International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme|discuss=Talk:International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme#Merger proposal|date=May 2017}} {{multiple image|right| | direction = vertical | width = 300 | footer = The Great Acceleration | image1 = Populationgrowth.jpg|frame|left| | image2 = Totalrealgdp.jpg|frame|left| | image3 = Foreigninvestment.jpg | image4 = Dammingofrivers.jpg | image5 = Wateruse.jpg | image6 = Paperconsumption.jpg | image7 = Motorvehicles.jpg | image8 = Telephones.jpg | image9 = Internationaltourism.jpg | image10 =Feriliserconsumption.jpg }} {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 300 | footer = Planetary response | image1 = Atmosphericco2concentration.jpg | image2 = Atmosphericn2oconcentrations.jpg | image3 = Atmosphericmethaneconcentrations.jpg | image4 = Ozonedepletion.jpg | image5 = Fisheriesexploited.jpg | image6 = Nitrogenflux.jpg | image7 = Forestloss.jpg | image8 = Domesticatedland.jpg | image9 = Speciesextinctions.jpg }}
'''Global change''' refers to planetary-scale changes in the [[Earth]] system. The system consists of the [[Terrestrial ecoregion|land]], [[oceans]], [[atmosphere]], [[polar region]]s, [[life]], the planet's natural cycles and deep Earth processes. These constituent parts influence one another. The Earth system now includes [[human society]], so global change also refers to large-scale changes in society.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.igbp.net/page.php?pid=101 |title=International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme the Earth as a System |accessdate=2010-03-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100429213905/http://www.igbp.net/page.php?pid=101 |archivedate=2010-04-29 |df= }} [[International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme]]</ref>
More completely, the term "global change" encompasses: [[population]], [[climate]], the [[economy]], resource use, [[energy development]], [[transport]], [[communication]], [[land use]] and [[land cover]], [[urbanization]], [[globalization]], [[atmospheric circulation]], [[ocean circulation]], the [[carbon cycle]], the [[nitrogen cycle]], the [[water cycle]] and other cycles, [[sea ice]] loss, [[sea-level rise]], [[food webs]], [[biological diversity]], [[pollution]], [[health]], [[over fishing]], and more.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iiasa.ac.at/Research/TNT/WEB/Publications/Abrupt_Changes/Abrupt_Changes.pdf|title=The Achilles Heel of the Earth System|accessdate=2010-03-25|publisher = [[International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis]]}}</ref>
== History of global-change research ==
In 1980, a group of scientists led by Swedish meteorologist [[Bert Bolin]] set up an international program called the [[World Climate Research Programme]] (WCRP), to determine whether the climate was changing, whether climate could be predicted and whether humans were in some way responsible for the change. The programme was sponsored by the [[World Meteorological Organization]] and the [[International Council for Science]] (ICSU). As time went on, there was a growing realisation that climate change was one part of a larger phenomenon, global change. In 1987, a team of researchers, led again by Bert Bolin, James McCarthy, [[Paul Crutzen]], H. Oeschger and others, successfully argued for an international research programme to investigate global change. This programme, sponsored by ICSU, is the [[International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme]] (IGBP). The programme has eight projects investigating different parts of the Earth system and links between them.
IGBP, WCRP and a third programme, the [[International Human Dimensions Programme]] (IHDP, founded in 1996), spearheaded a landmark science conference held in Amsterdam in 2001. The conference, ''Challenges of a Changing Earth: Global Change Open Science Conference'', led to the Amsterdam Declaration which stated, "In addition to the threat of significant climate change, there is growing concern over the ever-increasing human modification of other aspects of the global environment and the consequent implications for human well-being. Basic goods and services supplied by the planetary life support system, such as food, water, clean air and an environment conducive to human health, are being affected increasingly by global change."<ref name="The Amsterdam Declaration">{{cite web|url=http://www.essp.org/index.php?id=41|title=The Amsterdam Declaration|accessdate=2010-03-25|publisher=[[Earth System Science Partnership]]}}</ref>
The declaration goes on to say, "The international global change programmes urge governments, public and private institutions and people of the world to agree that an ethical framework for global stewardship and strategies for Earth System management are urgently needed."<ref name="The Amsterdam Declaration"/>
Many nations now have their own global change programmes and institutes, for example the US Global Change Research Program and the UK's Quantifying and Understanding the Earth System (QUEST) programme. And since the Amsterdam conference another international programme focusing on biodiversity has been set up, [[Diversitas|DIVERSITAS]]. These programmes form the Earth System Science Partnership.
In 2012, these international programmes held another major science conference in London, Planet Under Pressure: new knowledge towards solutions.<ref>{{Citation | url=https://erc.europa.eu/event/planet-under-pressure-new-knowledge-towards-solutions | title=Planet Under Pressure: New Knowledge Towards Solutions | date=2012 | publisher=European Research Council }}</ref>
== Causes ==
In the past, the main drivers of global change have been [[solar variation]], [[plate tectonics]], [[volcanism]], proliferation and abatement of [[life]], [[meteorite]] impact, resource depletion, changes in [[Earth]]'s orbit around the sun and changes in the tilt of Earth on its axis. There is overwhelming evidence that now the main driver of planetary-scale change, or global change, is the growing human population's [[energy demand|demand for energy]], food, goods, services and information, and its [[waste disposal|disposal]] of its [[waste]] products.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} In the last 250 years, global change has caused [[climate change]], [[Holocene extinction|widespread species extinction]]s, fish-stock collapse, [[desertification]], [[ocean acidification]], [[ozone depletion]], [[pollution]], and other large-scale shifts.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
Scientists working on the International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme have said that Earth is now operating in a "no analogue" state.<ref name="Global Change and the Earth System">{{cite web|url=http://www.igbp.net/page.php?pid=230|title=Global Change and the Earth System|accessdate=2010-03-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100429214445/http://www.igbp.net/page.php?pid=230|archivedate=2010-04-29|df=}}</ref> Measurements of Earth system processes, past and present, have led to the conclusion that the planet has moved well outside the range of natural variability in the last half million years at least. ''[[Homo sapiens]]'' have been around for about 200,000 years.
What this means for the planet and society remains unclear. But, in the last 20 years there has been an enormous international research effort to understand global change and the Earth system. An aim of this research is to work out if there are planetary boundaries and are we approaching them. Scientists, international governmental organizations and lobbying organizations like [[World Wide Fund for Nature]] argue that current consumption levels, particularly in developed countries, are not sustainable because there is a very real danger they will push the planet into a new state. What this new state might look like is still being debated, but sea levels are likely to rise several meters, the [[pH]] of the oceans, a measure of its acidity, is likely to drop farther than it has in 20 million years, and global atmospheric and ocean circulations may shift markedly. The major cycles – [[carbon]], [[nitrogen]], [[sulfur]], [[phosphorus]], [[water]] – and other important parameters would alter, bringing [[drought]] to some places, floods to others. Governments will no longer be able to take for granted the relative environmental stability that has allowed human society to flourish and led to rapid globalization. Most of the population of the planet will be affected. The [[re-insurance]] industry is already taking measures to protect its interests and maximize profits as turbulent times approach.
== Physical evidence ==
{{Refimprove|date=January 2017}}
Humans have always altered their environment. The advent of agriculture around 10000 years ago led to a radical change in land use that still continues. But, the relatively small human population had little impact on a global scale until the start of the [[industrial revolution]] in 1750. This event, followed by the invention of the [[Haber-Bosch]] process in 1909, which allowed large-scale manufacture of [[fertilizers]], led directly to rapid changes to many of the planet's most important physical, chemical and biological processes.
The 1950s marked a shift in gear: global change began accelerating. Between 1950 and 2010, the population more than doubled. In that time, rapid expansion of international trade coupled with upsurges in capital flows and new technologies, particularly information and communication technologies, led to national economies becoming more fully integrated. There was a tenfold increase in economic activity and the world's [[human population]] became more tightly connected than ever before. The period saw sixfold increases in water use and river damming. About 70 percent of the world's [[freshwater]] resource is now used for agriculture. This rises to 90 percent in India and China. Half of the Earth's land surface had now been domesticated. By 2010, urban population, for the first time, exceeded rural population. And there has been a fivefold increase in fertilizer use. Indeed, manufactured reactive nitrogen from fertilizer production and industry now exceeds global terrestrial production of reactive nitrogen. Without artificial fertilizers there would not be enough food to sustain a population of seven billion people.
These changes to the human sub-system have a direct influence on all components of the Earth system. The chemical composition of the atmosphere has changed significantly. Concentrations of important [[greenhouse gases]], [[carbon dioxide]], [[methane]] and [[nitrous oxide]] are rising fast. Over [[Antarctica]] a large hole in the ozone layer appeared. Fisheries collapsed: most of the world's fisheries are now fully or over-exploited. Thirty percent of tropical [[rainforests]] disappeared.
In 2000, Nobel prize-winning scientist [[Paul Crutzen]] announced the scale of change is so great that in just 250 years, human society has pushed the planet into a new geological era: the [[Anthropocene]]. This name has stuck and there are calls for the Anthropocene to be adopted officially. If it is, it may be the shortest of all geological eras. Evidence suggests that if human activities continue to change components of the Earth system, which are all interlinked, this could heave the Earth system out of a one state and into a new state.
== Society == Global change in a societal context encompasses social, cultural, technological, political, economic and legal change. Terms closely related to global change and society are [[globalization]] and global integration. Globalization began with long-distance trade and urbanism. The first record of long distance trading routes is in the third millennium BC. Sumerians in [[Mesopotamia]] traded with settlers in the [[Indus Valley]], in modern-day India.
Since 1750, but more significantly, since the 1950s, global integration has accelerated. This era has witnessed incredible global changes in communications, transportation, and computer technology. Ideas, [[cultures]], people, goods, services and money move around the planet with ease. This new global interconnectedness and free flow of information has radically altered notions of other cultures, [[Group conflict|conflicts]], [[religions]] and [[taboos]]. Now, social movements can and do form at a planetary scale.
Evidence, if more were needed, of the link between social and environmental global change came with the 2008-2009 global [[financial crisis]]. The crisis pushed the planet's main economic powerhouses, the [[United States]], [[Europe]] and much of [[Asia]] into recession. According to the [[Global Carbon Project]], global atmospheric emissions of carbon dioxide fell from an annual growth rate of around 3.4% between 2000 and 2008, to a growth rate of about 2% in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalcarbonproject.org/carbonbudget/08/hl-full.htm|title=2008 Global Carbon Budget|publisher=[[Global Carbon Project]]|accessdate=2010-03-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706160635/http://www.globalcarbonproject.org/carbonbudget/08/hl-full.htm|archivedate=2010-07-06|df=}}</ref>
== Planetary management == {{main|Planetary management}}
Humans are altering the planet's [[biogeochemical cycle]]s in a largely unregulated way with limited knowledge of the consequences.<ref name="Global Change and the Earth System"/> Without steps to effectively manage the Earth system – the planet's physical, chemical, biological and social components – it is likely there will be severe impacts on people and ecosystems. Perhaps the largest concern is that a component of the Earth system, for example, an [[ocean circulation]], the [[Amazon rainforest]], or [[Arctic]] sea ice, will reach a tipping point and flip from its current state to another state: flowing to not flowing, rainforest to [[savanna]], or ice to no ice. A domino effect could ensue with other components of the Earth system changing state rapidly.
Intensive research over the last 20 years has shown that tipping points do exist in the Earth system, and wide-scale change can be rapid – a matter of decades. Potential tipping points have been identified and attempts have been made to quantify thresholds. But to date, the best efforts can only identify loosely defined "[[planetary boundaries]]" beyond which tipping points exist but their precise locations remain elusive.
There have been calls for a better way to manage the environment on a planetary scale, sometimes referred to as managing "Earth's life support system". The [[United Nations]] was formed to stop wars and provide a platform for dialogue between countries. It was not created to avoid major environmental catastrophe on regional or global scales. But several international environmental conventions exist under the UN, including the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|Framework Convention on Climate Change]], [[Montreal Protocol]], [[United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification|Convention to Combat Desertification]], and [[Convention on Biological Diversity]]. Additionally, the UN has two bodies charged with coordinating environmental and development activities, the [[United Nations Environment Programme]] (UNEP) and the [[United Nations Development Programme]] (UNDP).
In 2004, the IGBP published "Global Change and the Earth System, a planet under pressure."<ref name="Global Change and the Earth System"/> The publication's executive summary concluded: "An overall, comprehensive, internally consistent strategy for stewardship of the Earth system is required". It stated that a research goal is to define and maintain a stable equilibrium in the global environment.
In 2007, France called for UNEP to be replaced by a new and more powerful organization called the "[[United Nations Environment Organization]]". The rationale was that UNEP's status as a "programme", rather than an "organization" in the tradition of the [[World Health Organization]] or the [[World Meteorological Organization]], weakened it to the extent that it was no longer fit for purpose given current knowledge of the state of the planet.{{citation needed|date=September 2011}}
== See also ==
*[[Biogeochemistry]] *[[Climate change]] *[[Earth system science]] *[[Global issue]] *[[Ozone depletion]] *[[Sustainability]] *[[Tipping point (climatology)]] ==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox video game | title = Gone Home | image = Gone Home.png | caption = Logo of ''Gone Home'' | developer = [[Fullbright (company)|The Fullbright Company]] | publisher = {{Unbulleted list|The Fullbright Company|[[Majesco Entertainment]] {{small|(PlayStation 4/Xbox One)}}|[[Annapurna Interactive]] {{small|(Switch)}}}} | engine = [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] | platforms = {{Unbulleted list|[[Linux]]|[[Microsoft Windows]]|[[OS X]]|[[PlayStation 4]]|[[Xbox One]]|[[Nintendo Switch]]}} | released = '''Windows''', '''OS X''', '''Linux'''{{Video game release|WW|15 August 2013}}'''PlayStation 4''', '''Xbox One'''{{Video game release|NA|12 January 2016|PAL|12 February 2016}}'''Nintendo Switch'''{{Video game release|WW|6 September 2018}} | genre = [[Adventure game|Adventure]], [[Exploration game|exploration]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | designer = Steve Gaynor | programmer = Johnnemann Nordhagen | artist = {{Unbulleted list|Karla Zimonja|Kate Craig|[[Emily Carroll]]}} | composer = [[Chris Remo]] }}
'''''Gone Home''''' is a [[First-person (video games)|first-person]] [[Exploration game|exploration]] and [[Adventure game#Walking simulators|walking simulator]] [[video game]] developed and published by [[Fullbright (company)|The Fullbright Company]]. ''Gone Home'' was first released for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[OS X]], and [[Linux]] computers in August 2013, followed by console released for the [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Xbox One]] in January 2016 and the [[Nintendo Switch]] in September 2018.
Set in the year 1995, ''Gone Home'' puts the player in the role of a young woman returning from overseas to her rural Oregon family home to find her family currently absent and the house empty, leaving her to piece together recent events. She comes to learn that her younger sister had recently come out as a [[lesbian]] to her family, creating strife with their parents that led to the current state of the house. Atypical of most video games, ''Gone Home'' does not feature much interactivity, but instead has the player explore the house at their own pace and determine what has transpired by examining items, journals, and other items left around the various rooms. The Fullbright team, having had previously worked on ''[[BioShock 2: Minerva's Den]]'', took concepts and ideas from that game to craft an exploration game to engage the player into uncovering the narration by non-linear progression in their searching of the house, while keeping the project manageable for their small team.
''Gone Home'' was critically praised at release. Several outlets used the game as an example of [[Video games as an art form|video games as art]], as its non-standard gameplay format demonstrates progression of the video game industry into more artistic forms. However, this also raised the question of whether ''Gone Home'' should be considered a game, and led to the derogatory term "walking simulators" to describe exploration games with little interactivity, though since then, the industry has come to embrace the term. ''Gone Home''{{'}}s characters story was praised for addressing [[LGBT]] issues with which some players could identify.
== Gameplay == The player takes the role of Katie in the [[First-person (video games)|first-person]] view, who can move around the house and view and interact with objects. There are no defined goals in the game; however, the game encourages and rewards the player when they explore new areas of the house and search for new messages. Much of the interactivity rests upon looking at objects and notes within the house. In order to progress in the game, the player must find certain objects that unlock access to other parts of the house.
== Plot == [[File:Gone Home - Launch Trailer.webm|thumb|left|thumbtime=69|320px|The launch trailer sets the scene for the game]] On 7 June 1995, 21-year-old Katie Greenbriar returns home from overseas to her family's new home in fictional Boon County, Oregon: her father, Terry, a failed writer who makes a living reviewing home electronics; her mother, Janice, a [[wildlife conservation]]ist who recently got promoted to director; and her 17-year-old sister Samantha. Upon arriving, she finds the house deserted, much of their possessions still in moving boxes, and a note on the door from Sam imploring Katie not to investigate what happened.<ref name=ign-2012/><ref>{{cite news|title=Gone Home transports players back to 1995|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2012-11-15-gone-home-preview-an-authentic-look-back-at-1995|first=Jeffrey|last=Matulef|date=15 November 2012|work=[[Eurogamer]]|accessdate=15 January 2013}}</ref>
Searching the house, Katie begins to piece together what happened during her absence: After moving in, Samantha found it difficult to adjust to her new high school, but eventually made friends with another girl, Yolanda "Lonnie" DeSoto, a [[Junior Reserve Officers' Training Corps|JROTC]] cadet. The two bonded over ''[[Street Fighter]]'', [[punk rock]], [[grunge]] and the burgeoning [[riot grrrl]] movement, and after sneaking off to a concert, the two became romantically involved. After various incidents at school, Sam's parents found out about her relationship, forbade Sam to close her bedroom door while Lonnie was over, and are in denial that their daughter is a lesbian. As Lonnie was set to eventually ship out to begin her service, Sam was left distraught.
Two days after her farewell show, which coincides with the day of Kaitlin's homecoming, and the week when Sam's parents are going on vacation (which is revealed to actually be a counseling trip instead of being a camping trip, like they told others) Lonnie departs to her station, but eventually calls Sam from a payphone to tell her that she got off the bus in [[Salem, Oregon|Salem]] and she wants them to be together. Sam's final journal entry to Katie explains that she packed up her things and took her car to find Lonnie, hoping to start a new life with her outside of Oregon.
Optionally, Katie can find various other clues that provide information on additional events that happened during the time: it is implied that Janice was beginning to have romantic feelings towards a subordinate, and that Terry was abused by Oscar Masan, his uncle and former owner of the house.
== Development == [[File:The_Fullbright_Company_-_Game_Developers_Choice_Awards_2014.jpg|thumb|right|The Fullbright Company at the [[Game Developers Choice Awards]] in 2014. From left, Kate Craig, Steve Gaynor, Johnnemann Nordhagen and Karla Zimonja]] [[Fullbright (company)|Fullbright]] was founded by Steve Gaynor, Karla Zimonja, and Johnnemann Nordhagen as "The Fullbright Company". The three had previously worked together at [[2K Games]] on ''[[BioShock 2: Minerva's Den]]''. All three were drawn by the prospect of developing an exploration game influenced by ''Minerva's Den'' through a small [[independent video game development|independent team]] rather than a large company, and subsequently left 2K Games to form Fullbright.<ref name="polygon fullbright"/><ref name="pcgamer 2013"/> To reduce costs, the team moved into a house together in [[Portland, Oregon]], and set up the office in the basement, with ''Gone Home'' being their first game.<ref name="polygon fullbright"/><ref name=EdgeProfile/> Gaynor considered their previous work on the ''BioShock'' games as effectively the pre-production stage for ''Gone Home'', allowing them to complete it within seventeen months.<ref name="pcgamersn 2017"/> The rapid development was aided by first prototyping the game in ''[[Amnesia: The Dark Descent]]''{{'}}s [[HPL Engine 2]] (which Gaynor had prior experience with), before completing the game in the [[Unity (game engine)|Unity 4]] [[game engine]].<ref name=JoystiqEngine>{{cite web| url=http://www.joystiq.com/2013/10/24/gone-home-began-as-an-amnesia-mod-and-you-can-play-it/| title=Gone Home began as an Amnesia mod, and you can play it| author=Danny Cowen| work=[[Joystiq]]| date=24 October 2013| accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref>
The initial concept for ''Gone Home'' was for the player to explore a [[Home automation|smart house]] that including a central [[artificial intelligence]] running everything with robots running around to complete tasks. The player would have been able to change the state of the house through their actions; Gaynor compared this idea to a non-combative ''[[System Shock]]'' game. As they explored this idea, and recognizing the small size of their team, they considered what would change if they made the house more like a regular household without any other characters visibly present, which significantly simplified the development into something more manageable for the team. This created the focus of the game as being "no other people, no other characters, [just] you in a single environment".<ref name=EdgeProfile>{{cite journal| title=Studio Profile: The Fullbright Company| author=Edge staff| journal=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]| issue=259| date=November 2013| pages=114–117}}</ref> The reduced scope allows them to complete the game with the three of them for programming, narrative, and 2D art assets, along with remote work from Kate Craig for the game's 3D modeling. Particularly, the smaller scope eliminated the need for any type of character modeler or animator.<ref name="pcgames 2015">{{Cite web | url = https://www.pcgamesn.com/gone-home/the-making-of-gone-home | title = The making of: Gone Home | first = Joe | last = Donnelley | date = 2 October 2015 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[PCGamesN]] }}</ref> Craig's wife [[Emily Carroll]], a comic artist whom Gaynor was a fan of, also assisted by designing some of the game's art asset and logos.<ref name="polygon fullbright">{{cite web | url = https://www.polygon.com/features/2013/8/13/4568900/the-fullbright-company-gone-home | title = Meet Me In Portland: The Fullbright Company's Journey Home | first = Mike | last = Mahardy | date = 13 August 2013 | accessdate = 16 August 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref>
Narratively, ''Gone Home'' was designed around family; Gaynor had stated that for all the science fiction trappings of ''Minerva's Den'', its core narrative was about a man, his wife, and how the man's past was affecting that relationship, and used the same approach for ''Gone Home''. They placed the player as one of the members of the family to remove any type of morality of exploring a house that did not belong to them. Additionally, they established that the family had only recently moved into the home; Gaynor had worried that the player would have difficulty identifying key elements that would be present among all the other objects within a well lived-in home, while within a recent move, only objects of immediate importance would have been unpacked, making it easy for the player to focus on these.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gamasutra.com/view/news/198340/How_Gone_Homes_design_constraints_lead_to_a_powerful_story.php | title = How Gone Home's design constraints lead to a powerful story | first= Leigh |last = Alexander | date =15 August 2013 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[Gamasutra]] }}</ref> Fullbright set the game in 1995 because they considered it the most recent year in which technology had not made the majority of communication digital in nature, so that they did not have to account for how digital communication would affect their storytelling, while still keeping elements of the game familiar to players.<ref name=ign-2012>{{cite news|title=Gone Home is Undiluted Adventure|url=http://ca.ign.com/articles/2012/11/15/gone-home-is-undiluted-adventure|first=Charles|last=Onyett|date=15 November 2012|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=15 January 2013}}</ref><ref name="pcgames 2015"/> Another source of inspiration was [[urban exploration]], particularly Japanese ''haikyo'', homes long abandoned due to industrialization. Gaynor said there were mysteries about its residents that people could put together from examining the state of the abandoned home.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://kotaku.com/5935262/how-modern-japanese-ruins-inspired-a-computer-game/ | title = How Modern Japanese Ruins Inspired a Computer Game | first = Brian | last= Ashcroft | date = 16 August 2012 | accessdate = 16 August 2018 | work = [[Kotaku]] }}</ref>
Gaynor statesd that ''Minerva's Den'' was more focused on environmental storytelling than action-driven gameplay, and set the approach and necessary design elements they needed for ''Gone Home''.<ref name="pcgamersn 2017">{{cite web | url = https://www.pcgamesn.com/bioshock-infinite/gone-home-tacoma | title = The BioShock games were pre-production for Gone Home | first = Jeremy | last = Peel | date = 9 August 2017 | accessdate = 9 August 2017 | work = [[PCGamesN]] }}</ref> Other elements that informed ''Gone Home'' from their ''BioShock'' experience was non-linear levels to explore, and discovering narrative elements through audio logs that the player would have to actively seek out, both which supported the exploration elements of the game.<ref name="pcgamer 2013">{{cite web | url = https://www.pcgamer.com/gone-home-steve-gaynor-interview/ | title = Gone Home interview with Steve Gaynor: BioShock, the '90s, and what makes a "game" | first = Tyler | last= Wilde | date =5 April 2013 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[PC Gamer]] }}</ref> Gaynor also considered the approach that [[Looking Glass Studios]] used for developing [[immersive sim]]s.<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.polygon.com/features/2015/4/6/8315901/looking-glass-gone-home |title = The Looking Glass Philosophy Behind Gone Home | first = Mike | last = Mahardy | date = 6 April 2018 | accessdate = 17 August 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref> One challenge that Fullbright considered was that not every player would necessarily find every narrative clue for the various plot elements, and so it was necessary for them to make the story flexible enough that the player could understand these narratives without necessarily seeing every element they designed.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/19/arts/video-games/in-gone-home-a-family-mystery-unfolds.html | title = Student’s Trip Ends; A Mystery Just Begins | first = Chris | last = Sullentop | date = 18 August 2013 | accessdate= 16 August 2018 | work = [[The New York Times]] }}</ref> Gaynor was aware this approach to a game would be considered unconventional, so they did not set out to make something avant-garde but instead more as a proof of concept that such games could be immersive to draw the player into to fully explore and come to understand the narrative themselves.<ref name=ign-2012/>
[[File:Gone Home - Zine.png|thumb|right|The player explores objects around the house to piece together the story. Much of game's art is influenced by the [[riot grrrl]] movement of the mid-1990s.]] The game features music from the [[riot grrrl]] bands [[Heavens to Betsy]] and [[Bratmobile]]; Fullbright knew of their Portland-based label [[Kill Rock Stars]], and worked early on with them to secure the rights to the music once they had settled on the locale and time period.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pcgamer.com/2013/03/21/gone-home-trailer-announces-music-from-90s-riot-grrrl-bands/ | author=Wilde, Tyler | title=Gone Home trailer announces music from ’90s riot grrrl bands Heavens to Betsy and Bratmobile | work=[[PC Gamer]] | date=21 March 2013 | accessdate=5 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.motherjones.com/media/2013/09/gone-home-women-in-video-games/ | title = Why This Indie Game Studio Chose a Feminist Drama Over Guns and Zombies | first = Matt | last = Connelly | date = 20 September 2013 | accessdate = 16 August 2018 | work = [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] }}</ref> After showing the game at Grrrl Front Fest, a Portland riot grrrl music festival, it attracted the attention of a local band, The Youngins, who went on to provide the music for Girlscout, the fictional band in the game.<ref name=EdgeProfile/><ref name=music>{{cite web | url=http://thefullbrightcompany.com/2013/08/14/the-music-of-gone-home/ | author=Gaynor, Steve | title=The Music of Gone Home | publisher=The Fullbright Company | date=14 August 2013 | accessdate=16 August 2013}}</ref> The game's original musical score was composed by [[Chris Remo]], Gaynor's friend and co-host from the ''[[Idle Thumbs]]'' podcast, and featuring over 30 minutes of music that accompany the game's main exploration gameplay, with unique music also scored to each of the game's audio logs.<ref name=music/>
A [[developer commentary]] mode was added as a free update to the game in October 2013.<ref name=IGNCommentary>{{cite web| url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2013/10/22/gone-home-updated-with-new-commentary-mode| title=Gone Home Updated With New Commentary Mode| author=Marty Sliva| work=[[IGN]]| date=24 October 2013| accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref>
=== Ports === A console version of the game was in development by Midnight City; however, this was later canceled following Midnight City's closure in March 2015.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Matulef|first1=Jeffery|title=Gone Home is no longer in development for consoles|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2015-03-03-gone-home-is-no-longer-in-development-for-consoles|website=Eurogamer|accessdate=4 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/gone-home-console-version-canceled/1100-6425677/|title=Gone Home Console Version Canceled}}</ref> Later, the development of the console port for [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Xbox One]] were switched to [[Majesco Entertainment]], and were released on 12 January 2016. These ports included enhanced graphics and audio, and used the updated [[Unity 5]] game engine.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.destructoid.com/gone-home-going-to-xbox-one-and-ps4-in-january-324818.phtml | title = Gone Home going to Xbox One and PS4 in January | last = Holmes | first = Jonathan | date = 7 December 2015 | website = [[Destructoid]] | publisher = [[ModernMethod]] | accessdate = 7 December 2015}}</ref>
''Gone Home'' was released for the [[Nintendo Switch]] on 6 September 2018 through support of publisher [[Annapurna Interactive]].<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-08-15-gone-home-moves-to-nintendo-switch-next-week | title = Gone Home moves to Nintendo Switch next week | first= Tom | last =Phillips | date = 15 August 2018 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[Eurogamer]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.usgamer.net/articles/gone-home-on-switch-delayed-to-september | title = Gone Home on Switch Delayed to September | first = Katy | last =McCarthy | date = 22 August 2018 | accessdate = 22 August 2018 | work = [[Eurogamer]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.polygon.com/2018/9/6/17827230/nintendo-switch-eshop-games-list | title = Gone Home and Hyper Light Drifter lead this week’s Nintendo eShop update | first = Ben | last = Kuchera | date = 6 September 2018 | accessdate = 7 September 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref> The Switch version includes licensed [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System]] game cartridge artwork on in-game objects, replacing fictional cartridges used in other versions, as part of the game's collaboration with Nintendo.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://kotaku.com/gone-homes-switch-version-has-official-snes-cartridges-1828955552 | title= Gone Home's Switch Version Has Official SNES Cartridges | first = Luke | last = Plunkett | date = 10 September 2018 | accessdate = 10 September 2018 |work = [[Kotaku]] }}</ref> Celebrating the game's fifth anniversary, Annapurna Interactive, in collaboration with [[iam8bit]], announced a limited physical release of the game for the Nintendo Switch, alongside a limited [[Phonograph record|vinyl record]] release for the game's soundtrack, to launch in Q1 2019.<ref name="NL cites physical Switch and vinyl">{{cite web |url=http://www.nintendolife.com/news/2018/09/gone_home_celebrates_fifth_anniversary_with_physical_release_on_nintendo_switch |date=7 September 2018 |accessdate=7 September 2018 |last=Doolan |first=Liam |website=[[Nintendo Life]] |title=Gone Home Celebrates Fifth Anniversary With Physical Release On Nintendo Switch}}</ref>
== Reception == {{Video game reviews | MC = PC: 86/100<ref name="MCPC">{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/gone-home |title=Gone Home for PC Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=4 December 2013}}</ref><br />PS4: 85/100<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-4/gone-home-console-edition |title=Gone Home: Console Edition for PlayStation 4 Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref> | AdvGamers = 4.5/5<ref name="AdventureGamers">{{cite web|url=http://www.adventuregamers.com/articles/view/25075|title=Gone Home review|date=16 August 2013|last=Morganti|first=Emily|accessdate=18 August 2013|publisher=[[Adventure Gamers]]}}</ref> | Edge = 9/10<ref name="Edge">{{cite web|url=http://www.edge-online.com/review/gone-home-review/|title=Gone Home Review|date=15 August 2013|accessdate=15 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206032050/http://www.edge-online.com/reviews/gone-home-review/|archivedate=6 February 2015}}</ref> | EuroG = 6/10<ref name="Eurogamer">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-08-15-gone-home-review|title=Gone Home review|date=15 August 2013|accessdate=18 August 2013|publisher=[[Eurogamer]]|last=Welsh|first=Oli}}</ref> | GI = 8.5/10<ref name="GameInformer">{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/gone_home/b/pc/archive/2013/08/15/gone-home-review.aspx|title=A Home Can Hold More Than You Think|last=Wallace|first=Kimberley|date=15 August 2013|accessdate=16 August 2013|publisher=[[Game Informer]]}}</ref> | GSpot = 9.5/10<ref name="GameSpot">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/gone-home-review/1900-6413000/|title=Gone Home Review|last=Petit|first=Carolyn|date=15 August 2013|accessdate=2 September 2013|publisher=[[GameSpot]]}}</ref> | GB = 5/5<ref name="GiantBomb">{{cite web|url=http://www.giantbomb.com/reviews/gone-home-review/1900-591/|title=Gone Home Review |last=Klepek|first=Patrick|date=15 August 2013|accessdate=16 August 2013|publisher=[[Giant Bomb]]}}</ref> | IGN = 9.5/10<ref name="IGN">{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/08/15/gone-home-review|title=Gone Home Review|last=Sliva|first=Marty|date=15 August 2013|accessdate=19 August 2013|publisher=IGN}}</ref> | PCGUS = 85/100<ref name="PC Gamer">{{cite news |title=Gone Home review |author=Logan Decker |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/review/gone-home-review/ |newspaper=[[PC Gamer (US)|PC Gamer]] |date=14 September 2013 |accessdate=15 September 2013}}</ref> | Poly = 10/10<ref name="Polygon">{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/game/gone-home/11272|title=Gone Home review : Living Room|date=15 August 2013|accessdate=19 August 2013|publisher=[[Polygon]]|last=Riendeau|first=Danielle}}</ref> | rev1 = ''[[Financial Post]]'' | rev1Score = 10/10<ref name="FinancialPost">{{cite web|url=http://business.financialpost.com/2013/08/15/gone-home-review-a-startling-and-unexpected-storytelling-triumph/|title=Gone Home review – A startling and unexpected storytelling triumph|last=Braga|first=Matthew|date=15 August 2013|accessdate=18 August 2013|publisher=[[Financial Post]]}}</ref> | rev2 = ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' | rev2Score = 4/5<ref>{{cite news |title=Gone Home review |author=Chris Schilling |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/video-games/video-game-reviews/10264724/Gone-Home-review.html |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=26 August 2013 |accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> | award1Pub = [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] | award1 = Best Debut Game (2013)<ref name="BBC 2014-03-12"/> | award2Pub = ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' | award2 = Game of the Year (2013)<ref name="Polygon 2014-01-15"/> }}
''Gone Home'' received very positive reviews from game journalists. At [[Metacritic]], the game holds an 86/100 score based on 56 critic reviews.<ref name="MCPC" />
Emily Morganti for ''[[Adventure Gamers]]'' commented that ''Gone Home'' had a "realistic, engrossing story that's beautifully told through environmental clues and audio narration" and that "many people read books for the opportunity to see life through someone else’s eyes, but it’s rare for a game to do it as well as this one does."<ref name="AdventureGamers"/> The ''[[Financial Post]]''{{'}}s Matthew Braga also noted that "This is a game that some will hold up as forward-thinking evidence in the ongoing debate of games-as-art", adding that the game was made to "plumb the depths of experience outside of gaming's typically targeted white, male, youthful core."<ref name="FinancialPost"/> However, ''[[Eurogamer]]'' editor Oli Welsh stated "The Fullbright Company has built a fine house for intimate storytelling in games, but it hasn't found the story to live in it yet."<ref name="Eurogamer"/>
The game's LGBT themes were praised.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.polygon.com/2013/8/19/4627606/opinion-finding-someone-like-me-in-gone-home | title = Opinion: Finding someone like me in Gone Home | first= Danielle | last = Riendeau |date = 19 August 2013 | accessdate =15 August 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.slate.com/blogs/outward/2013/11/12/video_games_embrace_gay_romance_from_the_ballad_of_gay_tony_to_the_last.html | title = The Gaying of Video Games | first = Terry | last = Mulcahy | date = 12 November 2013 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] }}</ref> Fullbright reported receiving numerous feedback not only from LGBT players of the game that appreciated how they told the story and how such people have to do deal with rejection by their family, but also from players who had opposed LGBT rights who found the game presented the issues related to LGBT to change their mind on the subject.<ref name="pcgames 2015"/> Fullbright also received some criticism from players from focusing on LGBT themes at the expense of other story elements.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/apr/10/sharing-joysticks-how-video-games-are-opening-up-to-lgbt-themes | title= Sharing joysticks: how video games are opening up to LGBT themes | first = Tim | last = Bowers | date = 10 April 2014 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[The Guardian]] }}</ref> Due to statements made by the organizers of [[PAX (event)|PAX Prime]] that Fulbright considered derogatory towards LGBT, the company pulled out of showing ''Gone Home'' at the Indie MEGABOOTH showcase during the 2013 PAX Prime event, stressing the importance of respecting LGBT issues.<ref name="TFC20130621">{{cite web|last=Gaynor|first=Steve|title=Why we are not showing Gone Home at PAX|url=http://thefullbrightcompany.com/2013/06/21/why-we-are-not-showing-gone-home-at-pax/|date=21 June 2013|accessdate=16 August 2013}}</ref><ref name="Gamasutra20130621">{{cite web|last=Ligman|first=Kris|title=Gone Home devs pull out of PAX Indie Megabooth|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/194849/Gone_Home_devs_pull_out_of_PAX_Indie_Megabooth.php|publisher=Gamasutra|date=21 June 2013|accessdate=16 August 2013}}</ref> In the wake of this, PAX announced that it would establish Diversity Hubs at its future events for "attendees to find information related to issues surrounding women, LGBTQ, people of color, disabled people, and mental health issues in gaming".<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.gamespot.com/articles/pax-addresses-inclusivity-with-addition-of-diversity-lounges/1100-6416795/ | title = PAX addresses inclusivity with addition of "Diversity Lounges" | first= Eddie | last = Makuch | date = 4 April 2014 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[GameSpot]] }}</ref>
Some reporters have considered the question of whether ''Gone Home'' should be considered a video game, as it lacks the normal interactivity one would normally have with a video game.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.wired.com/2013/08/gone-home-review/ | title= Gone Home: A Videogame, Without All That Pesky Videogame In The Way | first= Chris | last= Kohler | date= 15 August 2013 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]}}</ref> Gaynor asserted that ''Gone Home'' was specifically developed for the video game medium, stating that they considered it an "edited discussion" between Fullbright and the player, as "[t]he content that you encounter appears differently than for someone else. It is unique to each user and their interpretation. The interactivity of it makes the experience unique to yourself."<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.polygon.com/2014/3/31/5566098/gone-home-is-it-a-game | title = When is a game not a game? | first = Brian | last = Crecente | date = 31 March 2014 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref><ref name="pcgamer 2013"/> Gaynor used the example of the ability to turn lights on or off in any room in the house as an example of this. They included this interactivity as they had developed the game, they found that this gave a means for players to track if they had been within a room before or not, since the house starts otherwise dark, so he considered this one method by which they know what players would likely want to do and providing them means for them to do that, thus making the experience interactive.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/213612/What_makes_Gone_Home_a_game.php | title = What makes Gone Home a game? | first = Brandon | last = Sheffield | date = 20 March 2014 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[Gamasutra]] }}</ref> The lack of interactivity led to ''Gone Home'' to be derogatorily called "walking simulators" at its release, though since then, the industry has come to accept "walking simulators" to describe similarly contemplative narrative games with little direct interactivity, like ''[[The Stanley Parable]]'', ''[[Firewatch]]'', and ''[[What Remains of Edith Finch]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2014/06/28/walking-simulator-proteus-ed-key-ricky-haggett/ | title = Self-Interviewing Devs: Proteus And "Walking Simulators" | first = Alice | last = O'Conner | date = 28 June 2014 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[Rock Paper Shotgun]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.salon.com/2017/11/11/a-brief-history-of-the-walking-simulator-gamings-most-detested-genre/ | title = A brief history of the "walking simulator," gaming’s most detested genre | first = Nicole | last =Clark | date = 11 November 2017 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[Salon (magazine)|Salon]] }}</ref> ''Gone Home''{{'}}s approach to exploratory storytelling was a point of influence for parts of ''[[Uncharted 4: A Thief's End]]'' and ''[[Prey (2017 video game)|Prey]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.polygon.com/2016/4/4/11358228/uncharted-4-preview-single-player-story-hands-on-madagascar-ps4 | title = Uncharted 4 shines by making time for the quiet moments | first =Samit | last =Sarkar | date = 4 April 2016 | accessdate = 16 August 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://waypoint.vice.com/en_us/article/8x4j5b/how-the-queer-indie-game-gone-home-influenced-prey | title = How the Queer Indie Game 'Gone Home' Influenced 'Prey' | first = Danielle | last = Riendeau | date = 24 May 2017 | accessdate = 16 August 2018 | work = [[Vice (magazine)|Vice]] }}</ref>
Due to both the atypical nature of ''Gone Home'' and its narrative centered around LGBT issues, it became a central point of discussion at the onset of the [[Gamergate controversy]] in August 2014. A small portion of video game players that supported the apparent Gamergate movement criticized games like ''Gone Home'' and ''[[Depression Quest]]'' for lacking the qualities of normal video games and yet gained critical praise from the gaming press, as well as forcing players to accept topics like LGBT issues. Critics countered that these elements are part of considering [[video games as an art form]], demonstrating how the medium is changing.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/act-four/wp/2014/10/29/gamergate-reopens-the-debate-over-video-games-as-art | title = Gamergate reopens the debate over video games as art | first = Alyssa | last = Rosenberg | date = 29 October 2014 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[The Washington Post]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/26/opinion/sunday/the-disheartening-gamergate-campaign.html | title= Can Video Games Survive? | first = Chris | last =Sullentop | date = 26 October 2014 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[The New York Times]] }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.polygon.com/2018/9/7/17827216/gone-home-nintendo-switch-steve-gaynor-interview | title = As Gone Home turns five, we look back at its polarizing legacy | first= Allegra | last= Frank |date = 7 September 2018 | accessdate = 7 September 2018 | work = [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] }}</ref>
===Sales=== By September 2013, Fullbright announced that the game had sold more than 50,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thefullbrightcompany.com/2013/09/11/updates-ign-fantastic-fest-indiecade-and-initial-sales-numbers/|title=Updates: IGN, Fantastic Fest, Indiecade, and initial sales numbers|last=Gaynor|first=Steve|date=11 September 2013|work=The Fullbright Company|accessdate=12 September 2013}}</ref> By February 2014, sales had reached 250,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2014/02/06/gone-home-finds-250k-sales-most-on-steam/?ncid=rss_truncated|title=Gone Home finds 250K sales, most on Steam|last=Conditt|first=Jessica|date=6 February 2014|work=[[Joystiq]]|publisher=[[AOL]]|accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref> By the time of release of ''[[Tacoma (video game)|Tacoma]]'', Fullbright's second game released in October 2017, ''Gone Home'' had sold more than 700,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.pcgamer.com/gone-home-prevented-tacoma-from-being-judged-on-its-own-says-creator-steve-gaynor/ | title = Gone Home prevented Tacoma from being judged on its own, says creator Steve Gaynor | first = Joe | last = Donnelley | date = 3 October 2017 | accessdate = 15 August 2018 | work = [[PC Gamer]] }}</ref>
===Awards and accolades=== The game was also nominated for "Excellence in Narrative" for the [[Independent Games Festival]] for 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/188908/Road_to_the_IGF_The_Fullbright_Companys_Gone_Home.php | title = Road to the IGF: The Fullbright Company's Gone Home | first = Leigh | last = Alexander | date = 20 March 2014 | accessdate= 16 August 2018 | work = [[Gamasutra]] }}</ref>
''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' named ''Gone Home'' their Game of the Year for 2013.<ref name="Polygon 2014-01-15">{{cite web |url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/1/15/5311568/game-of-the-year-2013-gone-home |title=Polygon's 2013 Game of the Year: Gone Home |first=Christopher |last=Grant |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |date=15 January 2014 |accessdate=15 January 2014}}</ref>
''Gone Home'' was nominated for several categories at the 2014 [[Game Developers Choice Awards]], including "Game of the Year", "Innovation Award", "Best Narrative", and "Best Downloadable Game", while Fullbright won as a studio for "Best Debut" for ''Gone Home''.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.engadget.com/2014/01/09/gone-home-the-last-of-us-tearaway-top-gdc-award-nominations/ | title = Gone Home, The Last of Us, Tearaway top GDC Award nominations | first = Dave | last = Hinkle | date = 9 January 2014 | accessdate = 16 August 2018 | work = [[Engadget]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.engadget.com/2014/03/20/papers-please-and-the-last-of-us-honored-at-gdc-awards-show/ | title =Papers, Please and The Last of Us honored at GDC awards show | first = Ludwig | last = Kietzman |date = 20 March 2018 | accessdate = 16 August 2018 | work = [[Engadget]] }}</ref>
The game won the 2013 [[British Academy Games Awards]] for best "Debut Game" while nominated for "Best Story".<ref name="BBC 2014-03-12">{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-26549269 | title = Bafta games: The Last of Us clears up at awards | first= Dave | last = Lee | date= 12 March 2014 | accessdate = 12 March 2014 | publisher = [[BBC]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://static.bafta.org/files/games-nominations-2014-2166.pdf | title = BAFTA Video Game Awards - Nominations | date = 12 February 2014 | accessdate = 12 February 2014 | publisher = [[BAFTA]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140222214648/http://static.bafta.org/files/games-nominations-2014-2166.pdf | archivedate = 22 February 2014 | df = }}</ref> {{-}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6)
revision.text:
{{one source|date=June 2015}} The '''Hawkeye State''' is a nickname for the state of [[Iowa]]. According to the state's tourism web site, "Two Iowa promoters from [[Burlington, Iowa|Burlington]] are believed to have popularized the name."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.traveliowa.com/aspx/general/dynamicpage.aspx?id=37|title=State Symbols: Iowa Tourism Map, Travel Guide, Things to Do: Travel Iowa|accessdate=2013-10-12|publisher=Iowa Economic Development|author=|date=}}</ref> The nickname was given approval by [[Iowa Territory|territorial officials]] in 1838, eight years before Iowa became a state.
The men responsible for the promotion of this nickname are thought to be Judge [[David Rorer]] of Burlington and newspaper publisher [[James G. Edwards]]. The city of Burlington had been established in 1833 after the previous year's [[Black Hawk War]]. Edwards changed the name of his Burlington newspaper, ''The Iowa Patriot'', to ''The Hawk-Eye and Iowa Patriot'' in tribute to friend [[Chief Black Hawk]], a [[Sauk people|Sauk]] leader. Edwards proposed the nickname "Hawk-eyes" in 1838 to "...rescue from oblivion a memento, at least, of the name of the old chief", Black Hawk.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cYQUAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22at%20least%20of%20the%20name%20of%20the%20old%20chief%22&pg=PA425#v=onepage&q=%22at%20least%20of%20the%20name%20of%20the%20old%20chief%22&f=false | title=The history of Des Moines County, Iowa | year=1879 | pages=425}}</ref> The [[University of Iowa]]'s athletic teams are nicknamed the [[Hawkeyes]] and feature a mascot named [[Herky the Hawk]].
The University of Iowa borrowed its athletic nickname from the state of Iowa. The name Hawkeye was originally applied to a hero in a fictional novel, [[The Last of the Mohicans]], written by [[James Fenimore Cooper]]; the author had the [[Lenape|Delaware Indians]] bestow the name on a white scout who lived and hunted with them.
In 1838, 12 years after the book was published, people in the territory of Iowa acquired the nickname, chiefly through the efforts of Judge David Rorer of Burlington and James G. Edwards of Fort Madison. Edwards, editor of the Fort Madison Patriot, moved his newspaper to Burlington in 1843 and renamed it the Burlington Hawkeye. The two men continued their campaign to popularize the name and were rewarded when territorial officials gave it their formal approval.
The Hawkeye nickname gained a tangible symbol in 1948 when a cartoon character, later to be named [[Herky the Hawk]], was hatched. The creator was Richard Spencer III, instructor of journalism. The impish hawk was an immediate hit and he acquired a name through a statewide contest staged by the UI Athletic Department. John Franklin, a Belle Plaine alumnus, was the man who suggested Herky.<ref>[http://www.hawkeyesports.com/trads/herky.html University of Iowa Athletics] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019050234/http://www.hawkeyesports.com/trads/herky.html |date=2012-10-19 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Symbols of Iowa]] [[Category:Names of places in the United States]] [[Category:American toponymy]] [[Category:Nicknames]]

{{Infobox company | name = Japan Radio Co., Ltd. | native_name = 日本無線株式会社 | native_name_lang = jp | logo = JRC company logos.svg | logo_size = 260px | image = Nakano Central Park East.jpg | image_size = 230px | image_caption = The company's headquarters | type = [[public company|Public]] [[Kabushiki kaisha|KK]] | traded_as = {{TYO|6751}} | ISIN = JP3751800008 | founded = ({{Start date and age|1915|12}}) | hq_location_city = Nakano Central Park East, [[Nakano, Tokyo|Nakano-ku, Tokyo]] 164-8570 | hq_location_country = Japan | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Takayoshi Tsuchida
([[Chairman#Public corporations|Chairman]])
Kenji Ara
([[President (corporate title)|President]]) | industry = [[Electronics]] | products = {{unbulleted list|Communication systems|Navigation systems|Fishing systems|Broadcasting equipment|Aviation and meteorological systems|Disaster prevention systems|Landslide monitoring systems|Water and river management}} | revenue = [[Japanese yen|JPY]] 125.1 billion ([[Fiscal year|FY]] 2015) ([[US dollar|US$]] 1.1 billion) (FY 2015) | net_income = JPY 1.6 billion (FY 2015) (US$ 14.7 million) (FY 2015) | num_employees = 5,575 (consolidated as of March 31, 2016) | footnotes = {{cite web |url=http://www.jrc.co.jp/eng/about/company/overview.html |title=Company Data |publisher=Japan Radio Company |accessdate=April 21, 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://asia.nikkei.com/Company/05HZHK-E |title=Company Profile |work=[[Nikkei Asian Review]] |publisher=[[Nikkei Inc.]] |accessdate=April 21, 2017}} | website = {{Official website|http://www.jrc.co.jp/eng/index.html}} }} {{nihongo|'''Japan Radio Co., Ltd.'''|日本無線株式会社|Nihon Musen Kabushiki-gaisha}} is a [[Japan]]ese company specialising in the field of [[wireless]] electronics for the communications industry. == History == Established in 1915, the company has produced a wide variety of products including [[Marine (ocean)|marine]] [[electronics]], measuring equipment for [[telecommunication]], [[radio broadcasting]] equipment, and [[amateur radio]] equipment, including the JST-145dx/JST-245dx HF transceivers, which were the last amateur radio transceivers produced by JRC, ending in 2002. Even though these transceivers have been out of production {{As of|April 2015|alt=over 10 years}}, they still compete in performance with current{{When|date=April 2015}} high-end amateur transceivers available from other amateur radio manufacturers today,{{When|date=April 2015}} and have become prized possessions of the hams that are fortunate enough to own one. JRC still supports these radios through 2015, per information on their Web site. [[File:JPRC-C1 SATCOM terminal.jpg|center|thumb|[[Japan Ground Self-Defense Force|JGSDF]] '''JPRC-C1''' SATCOM ([[Satellite Communications]]) terminal]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == {{Portal|Tokyo|Electronics|Companies}} *[http://www.jrc.co.jp/eng/index.html JRC global site] {{en icon}} *[http://www.jrceurope.com/ JRC Europe site] *[http://www.jrcamerica.com/ JRC America site] {{Electronics industry in Japan}} [[Category:Electronics companies of Japan]] [[Category:Defense companies of Japan]] [[Category:Avionics companies]] [[Category:Marine electronics]] [[Category:Navigation system companies]] [[Category:Electronics companies established in 1915]] [[Category:1915 establishments in Japan]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Companies based in Tokyo]] [[Category:Amateur radio companies]] [[Category:Public safety communications]] [[Category:Global Positioning System]] [[Category:Japanese brands]] {{japan-company-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Chinese cuisine}} [[Chinese desserts]] are [[sweet]] foods and dishes that are served with [[Chinese tea|tea]], along with meals<ref name="kaleidoscope">[http://kaleidoscope.cultural-china.com/en/8Kaleidoscope5550.html "Chinese Desserts."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110702152953/http://kaleidoscope.cultural-china.com/en/8Kaleidoscope5550.html |date=2011-07-02 }} [http://kaleidoscope.cultural-china.com Kaleidoscope - Cultural China] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711102415/http://kaleidoscope.cultural-china.com/ |date=2011-07-11 }}. Accessed June 2011.</ref> or at the end of meals in [[Chinese cuisine]]. The desserts encompass a wide variety of [[ingredient]]s commonly used in East [[Asian cuisine]]s such as powdered or whole [[glutinous rice]], [[sweet bean paste]]s, and [[agar]]. Due to the many [[Chinese culture]]s and the long [[history of China]], there are a great variety of desserts of many forms.
{{Compact ToC|center=yes|align=center|seealso=yes|notesfirst=|extlinks=no|refs=yes|sep=·}}
==Chinese desserts==
===A=== [[File:Anninndofu-1-.jpg|thumb|[[Almond jelly]] is a popular dessert, often found in [[dim sum]] restaurants worldwide.]] * [[Annin tofu]]
===B=== * [[Banana roll]] * [[Black sesame roll]] * [[Black sesame soup]]
===C=== [[File:Coconutbar.jpg|thumb|A [[coconut bar]] is a [[refrigerated]] dim sum dessert that is sometimes referred to as coconut pudding, despite not really being a [[pudding]].<ref>[http://www.ifood.tv/network/coconut_bar Coconut Bar]. iFood TV. Accessed March 31, 2012.</ref>]] * [[Chao hong guo]] * [[Chinese bakery products]] * [[Chongyang Cake]] — 9 September of each Chinese lunar calendar * [[Coconut bar]] * [[Crystal cake]] * [[Custard tart]] * [[Cut cake]]
===D=== * [[Douhua]] * [[Dragon's beard candy]]
===E=== [[File:Egg custard tart by Stu Spivack.jpg|thumb|Egg custard tarts is a popular Chinese pastry]] * [[Egg tart]] * [[Egg tong sui]] * [[Eggies]] * [[Eight treasure congee]]
===F=== [[File:FriedIceCream.jpg|thumb|Fried ice cream is a dessert made from a breaded scoop of [[ice cream]] that is quickly deep-fried, creating a warm, crispy shell around the still-cold ice cream.]] * [[Fried ice cream]] * [[Funing big cake]]
===G=== * [[Ginger milk curd]] * [[Grass jelly]] * [[Guilinggao]]
<gallery class="center" caption="" widths="200px" heights="145px"> File:Ginger Milk Pudding.jpg|[[Ginger milk curd]] is a hot dessert that originated in Shawan town of [[Panyu]] District, [[Guangzhou]] in the [[Guangdong Province]] in [[northern and southern China|southern]] [[China]]. Its main ingredients are [[ginger]], [[milk]], and [[sugar]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tastehongkong.com/recipes/ginger-milk-pudding-a-natural-custard/|title=Ginger Milk Pudding, a Natural Custard|author=|work=tastehongkong.com|date=29 March 2011|accessdate=13 August 2012}}</ref> File:GrassJellyBlocks.jpg|[[Grass jelly]] is a [[Gelatin|jelly-like]] dessert that is prepared with ''[[Mesona chinensis]]''. </gallery>
===H=== [[File:Shaobing5.jpg|thumb|Shaobing or [[Huangqiao Sesame Cake|sesame cake]] originated from Huangqiao town in Taixing, Jiangsu.]] * [[Hasma]] * [[Huangqiao sesame cake]]
===J=== * [[Jiuniang]] * [[JingBaJian]]
===K=== * [[Kai kou xiao]]
===L=== * [[Ligao Tang]] * [[Lotus seed paste]]
===M=== [[File:Mango pudding.JPG|thumb|[[Mango pudding]] is a Hong Kong dessert usually served cold.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnngo.com/hong-kong/eat/around-asiacitation|title=8 bone-chilling summer desserts for Hong Kong|author=Andrew Dembina |work=CNN Go|date=26 August 2010|accessdate=12 August 2012}}</ref>]] [[File:Moon Cakes.jpg|thumb|[[Mooncakes]] are traditionally eaten during the Mid-Autumn Festival.]] * [[Mahua (snack)|Mahua]] * [[Mango pudding]] * [[Mi san dao]] * [[Mooncake]]
===N=== [[File:Guangdong Nian cake.jpg|thumb|Popular Guangdong deep-fried sweet [[nian gao]]]] * [[Nai lao]] * [[Nian gao]] * [[Nuomici]]
===O=== * [[Orange jelly candy]]
===P=== * [[Pandan cake]] * [[Put chai ko]]
===R=== * [[Red bean cake]] * [[Red bean soup]] * [[Red tortoise cake]] * [[Rice pudding]] * [[Red bean bun]]
===S=== * [[Sachima]] * [[Song gao]] * [[Sugar painting]] * [[Sweet potato soup]] * [[Sweetheart cake]]<ref>[http://indochinekitchen.com/2008/11/chinese-sweetheart-cake/ Chinese-sweetheart-cake]</ref>
<gallery class="center" caption="" widths="175px" heights="175px"> File:Chinese sugar painting 01.jpg|[[Sugar painting]] is a traditional Chinese form of [[folk art]] using hot, liquid sugar to create two-dimensional figures. File:Wifecake.jpg|[[Sweetheart cake]] is a traditional [[Cantonese cuisine|Cantonese]] [[pastry]] with flaky and thin skin filled with [[winter melon]] mixed [[glutinous rice]] flour and sugar. Coconut, sesame, almond, [[star anise]] or [[Chinese five spice]] may also be added. </gallery>
===T=== * [[Tanghulu]] * [[Tangyuan (food)|Tangyuan]] * [[Tapioca pudding]] * [[Taro purée]] * [[Tong sui]]
<gallery class="center" caption="" widths="200px" heights="145px"> File:Bingtanghulu.JPG|[[Tanghulu]] is a traditional Chinese snack of candied fruit. File:Pumpkin tangyuan (汤圆) with red bean baste and black sesame fillings.jpg|Pumpkin tang yuan ({{zh|s=汤圆}}) with red bean paste and black sesame fillings </gallery>
===W=== * [[White Rabbit Creamy Candy]] * [[White sugar sponge cake]]
===X=== * [[Xi gua lao]]

text-align:left;"|Main title / alternate title(s) !style="width:15%; text-align:left;"|Developer !style="width:11%; text-align:left;"|Release date !style="width:44%; text-align:left;"|System(s) |-
